[kafka-trunk-git-pr #97](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/97/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

@hachikuji Thanks for your quick review.

1) Currently the only use case we envision for this callback in seek() is when the position to seek is out of range. Since a rebalance will change the offset and invalidate the previous seek, I think we can invalidate the callback as well.

2) Yes, on a double think I think it will be useful to include the TopicPartition and the offset that was seeked to in the callback. This will be useful upon OFFSET_OUT_OF_RANGE exception.

3) Due to the use case of this callback, I personally don't think it is useful to include it in seekToBeginning and seekToEnd. I would also like to see what others think of this.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #110](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/110/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

This is the failure:

> kafka.api.ConsumerBounceTest > testSeekAndCommitWithBrokerFailures FAILED
>     kafka.common.KafkaException: Socket server failed to bind to localhost:54667: Address already in use.
>         at kafka.network.Acceptor.openServerSocket(SocketServer.scala:281)

This may be related to open file handles. The unit tests have a lot of them. Not sure if they are leaking. There have been some discussions here:
- [KAFKA-2398](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2398)
- [Kafka Unit Test Failures on a Mac](http://search-hadoop.com/m/uyzND1hazyw1XiDyH1/Kafka+Unit+Test+Failures+on+a+Mac&subj=Kafka+Unit+Test+Failures+on+a+Mac)
- [KAFKA-1782](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-1782)
@ijuma LGTM
@onurkaraman Would it be worthwhile to add a test case for shrinking the subscription set?
Hey Jason. Yeah I was thinking the same! I'll add it now.

This pull request looks good

@ijuma : should I squash the commits and force push? I'm not a fan of having these multiple commits, but I read that this would remove all the earlier comments from the pull request.

It looks like recent git commit messages in the git log show all the intermediate commits, which is something I'd like to avoid.

@onurkaraman, good question. My preference is the same as yours, to squash any commits that don't add any value. However, this is not a requirement of the Kafka project at this stage, so it's up to the submitter.

There are two options if you want to squash:
- Force push to the same branch. Comments on commits may disappear (sometimes they stay with a note about being for an out of date commit), but comments on the PR itself will remain. I personally think this is OK for PRs like this where the comments were all addressed anyway.
- Create a new PR and reference the previous one. This is better for complex PRs where there are a lot of comments.
@ijuma thanks. The squash and force push worked!

> Despite our efforts, Kafka may have flaky tests at any given point, which may cause a build to fail. Unfortunately, it's not currently possible to restart the build by issuing a command... A workaround is to close and reopen the PR. If the failure is unrelated to your pull request and you have been able to run the tests locally successfully, please mention it in the pull request.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM.

@lazyval , ideally the exception returned by leader should contain more information. However, that is a big wire protocol change and perhaps not necessary. The easier fix is to handle the exception correctly. So the problem is how to deal with the race condition. The follower is not confused in this case, it just needs one more check to understand the situation.
@granders A couple of minor comments, but LGTM.

I agree with @hachikuji that the callback should always be invoked. If it isn't, then I think there would need to be some _very_ clear javadocs indicating when it is/isn't invoked. Any use of this callback also requires implementing a ConsumerRebalanceCallback if you hold on to any state while waiting for the callback.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #122](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/122/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

@ewencp @hachikuji. Thanks for the suggestion! I have updated the patch such that the ConumserSeekCallback is always invoked, including when SubscriptionState.clearAssignment() and SubscriptionState.clearPartition(). I am not sure why the use of this callback also requires  implementing a ConsumerRebalanceCallback though. Let me double think on this.

@lindong28 I only meant it required implementing ConsumerRebalanceCallback if it _didn't_ get invoked in some cases. If the application did something like invoke the commit and wait for the callback, meanwhile holding on to resources, but the callback wasn't guaranteed to be invoked if a rebalance occurred in the meantime, then the only way to correctly clean up the resources associated with the callback would be to implement a ConsumerRebalanceCallback to clean them up.

If we guarantee the callback is always invoked, then this is no longer necessary (and simplifies application code that uses this callback).

@lindong28 @ewencp I think the thing that's bugging me about the callback is that the semantics seem strange. When the consumer invokes seek(), the position is updated immediately and position() will return the seeked position. It's only later that the user finds out if that position is out of range. Intuitively, I would expect the callback to be invoked when the position is updated. I wonder if instead of using the generic ConsumerSeekCallback, the behavior would be clearer with an OffsetOutOfRangeCallback, which is only invoked when that error occurs? Then we wouldn't have to worry about ensuring the callback is invoked in all cases and it would make sense for the position to be updated immediately. Does that make sense?

LGTM

@lazyval Apologies for the commits history, I was fighting with git merge history back then from two branches and hence the commits was not well organized. I will create another PR with squashed commits after addressing the collected comments from this PR.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #126](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/126/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good
@fpj, can you please take a look at this when you have a chance?

@ewencp Usually when we get the offset out of range error, we just reset the position, so i wouldn't see that callback as one which could be invoked multiple times. The callback just provides a way to override the default reset behavior. It's also intuitive in my opinion to be able to handle the error at the same location in the code that the seek is performed.

I agree, however, that this is still not great. The user might want to intercept all out of range errors, not just the ones that result from a specific seek. The `ConsumerListener` interface could be interesting (at the very least, I definitely would approve of changing `ConsumerRebalanceCallback` to `ConsumerRebalanceListener`). It might be worthwhile to spend a little time trying to flesh out a basic sketch of the interface for comparison.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #127](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/127/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

@ewencp @hachikuji I think we are discussing to things: 1) whether it is more intuitive to call it ConsumerSeekCallback or OffsetOutOfRangeCallback; 2) whether we should turn it and other callback into listener instead. I agree with your opinion on 2). But 2) goes beyond the scope of this ticket and requires much detailed discussion since it changes the user interface (e.g. ConsumerRebalanceListener). Can we focus on 1) first?

I would prefer ConsumerSeekCallback to OffsetOutOfRangeCallback. If the user expects ConsumerSeekCallback to be invoked when position is updated, shouldn't he has the same expectation for OffsetOutOfRangeCallback? By keeping ConsumerSeekCallback, we have a more general callback API, and we can ensure that it is always invoked, including when rebalance happens or when user re-subscribe to partitions. We can describe in the document that seek() is actually an asynchronous API and it is only effective when the fetch after the seek gets a non-error response.
Good comments from Grant. Other than that this change looks good.

hi @guozhangwang @ijuma 

Thanks for reviewing this patch. I have updated it according to your comments. The two main things I have done are to wrap all calls to sendRequestToBrokers with a try/catch block (previously I was only doing it in the one that caused the bug described in the jira) and to fix the strings as you pointed out. [kafka-trunk-git-pr #131](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/131/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

@gwenshap Trivial patch since I just stole this code from Hadoop. Do we want to also want to run through all the existing code and mark, e.g., the new producer classes as stable as part of this patch?

I'm also not sure if we really need all 3 of stable, evolving, and unstable. I don't think we've ever treated anything as being in the evolving state. Or perhaps we should have one release cycle for major new features like the new consumer where we mark them as evolving so we have an out if we end up needing to make a compatibility breaking change?

Currently we have exactly two modes:
- Don't break compatibility ever (most of the code base)
- May change unexpectedly at any time (New consumer)

I like the idea of first releasing new major components as "evolving" for the first release, since (as we found out with the new producer) when more people use the API, deficiencies get discovered and stabilizing the APIs too soon may lock us into bad APIs.

Regarding existing code... I'm neutral. Both marking and leaving unmarked for now seems reasonable.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #132](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/132/) SUCCESS
